Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fixing Stellar Chronometers With Open Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
A star's age is one of its most fundamental parameters. It is also, for isolated 'field' stars, notoriously difficult to measure accurately. Two standard stellar chronometers - the age-rotation and age-activity relations - generally struggle to produce age estimates with uncertainties better than 50%. The PI will tackle this problem by combining a wealth of new observations from the Palomar Transient Factory Open Cluster Survey with follow-up spectroscopy and X-ray observations. He will assemble a complete, uniform sample of rotation periods and activity measurements for low-mass stars in six open clusters ranging in age from 35 Myr to 2.5 Gyr. By examining the relationships between stellar age, rotation, and activity, he will address three basic questions: (1) the rotational period distribution of low mass zero-age main sequence stars, (2) the evolution of rotational periods of low mass stars with ages > 500 My, and (3) the possible divergence of age-activity and age-rotation relations at ages > 500 My. The work will provide a significant leap in our understanding of stellar ages. In turn, this will inform us about the composition and internal structure of stars, and it will allow us to better understand stellar magnetic fields.

The PI will also perform a wide-ranging set of synergistic education and outreach activities centered on ensuring that students from underrepresented minorities have successful transitions into graduate school. As the Director of Columbia University's Bridge to the Ph.D. in the Natural Sciences scheme, he will play a leading role in recruiting, mentoring, and educating post-baccalaureate minority students in a structured program designed to ensure their continued success in Ph.D. programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Palomar Transient Factory (PTF) Open Cluster Survey was an effort to map rotational periods and magnetic activity in low-mass stars using observations of six open clusters ranging in age from 35 Myr to 2.5 Gyr. The survey was designed so that the data collected would enable an unprecedented calibration of two standard stellar chronometers, the age-rotation and age-activity relations, and allow us to answer a simple but vexing question: how old is that star?

Sun-like stars change very little during their long main-sequence lifetimes, making their ages one of their most challenging properties to determine. However, knowing stellar ages, especially for low-mass stars (≤1 solar mass), is essential in this era of precision astrophysics. Our current inability to provide confident ages for these stars limits our understanding of the Milky Way’s star-formation and chemical-enrichment histories, for example. But it is the recent explosion of interest in finding exoplanets and determining their habitability that has given the question of how to determine the ages of low-mass stars a new urgency, because potentially habitable, Earth-like planets are most likely to be discovered orbiting these stars.

We have known for 45+ years that low-mass stars do have built-in clocks: their rotation periods  and their magnetic activity, which are interdependent. These stars spin down over time via magnetic braking, and this coupling of magnetic activity and rotation causes their coronal X-ray luminosity and the strength of their chromospheric emission lines to wane with time as well. However, in his 2010 Annual Review article, The Ages of Stars, David Soderblom found that typical empirical estimates of stellar ages have uncertainties of order 20-50%. Worse, when independent methods for estimating ages are applied to the same stars, these disagree by 50%.

The PTF Open Cluster Survey combined new measurements and those available in the literature to construct a complete, uniform sample of rotation periods and activity measurements for <1 solar-mass stars in six open clusters: Alpha Persei (35 Myr), the Pleiades (120 Myr), M37 (500 Myr), Praesepe (600 Myr), NGC 752 (1.9 Gyr), and Ruprecht 147 (2.5 Gyr). The survey aimed to produce a complete description of the age-rotation and age-activity relations for low-mass stars from their arrival on the zero-age main sequence until they are half the Sun's age.

Over the lifetime of the grant, my group has published 16 peer-reviewed publications on topics related to those that motivated the original proposal. While M37, Praesepe, and the Hyades have been the focus of the bulk of those publications, we have worked on rotation and activity in all six of the open clusters listed above. Our results for Ruprecht 147 should be submitted in early 2020, with a final paper on our work on Alpha Persei scheduled for later in 2020.

Along the way, our focus shifted to using K2 to measure rotation periods, and in early 2019 we published the first paper using TESS data to establish a rotation-based age for a stellar population (the Gaia-discovered Pisces-Eridanus Stream). It is also worth noting that our work moved in unexpected directions, included examining the consistency of elemental abundances in Praesepe (as a test of the in-vogue idea of chemical tagging) and using simultaneous photometric and spectroscopic monitoring to study the relationship between different manifestations of magnetic activity.

The project supported two Ph.D. theses, with the most recent being defended in August 2018. It also supported a Bridge-to-PhD participant for two years and another post-baccalaureate researcher for three years, and in the summer of 2019 it supported an undergraduate researcher.

This grant also supported the (now renamed) Bridge to the Ph.D. Program in STEM, which is thriving. We have a full-time director housed in Columbia's Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science, which in 2019-20 is supporting two participants in the Program and will start supporting four in 2020-21. Meanwhile, the School of Arts & Sciences has committed to supporting five participants a year for the next three years. And in 2019-20, the Department of Economics joined the Program, adding two participants. Our challenge now is insuring that the quality of the mentoring we provide to our participants remains high, especially as other entities are interested in joining the Program.

More broadly, the Bridge Program is now part of the university landscape in a way that seemed unlikely even three years ago. It is also clearly part of a national landscape that has been more and more willing to incorporate bridge programs into its thinking about how to enhance underrepresented minority participation in STEM. Examples of this include the recent launch of the American Chemical Society's Bridge Program, modeled on the American Physical Society's program (which itself was modeled in part on Columbia's), and the growing recognition that graduate programs should move toward holistic admissions, a feature of bridge program admissions since their inception.
